REPORT OF THE AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS.
The State of Nebraska,
Office of Auditor of Public Account
Lincoln, December 1, 1902.
To His Excellency, Ezra P. Savage, Governor of the State of Nebraska
Dear Sir — I have the honor to transmit herewith the biennial report of this department of the state government for the two years ending November 30, 1902, in pursuance of section 22, article 5 of the constitution, and section 3, article 3, chapter 83, Compiled Statutes of 1901.
The above cited section of the Compiled Statutes of 1901 requires that this report shall contain a full and detailed statement tthe condition of the treasury: a full and detailed statement of public debt; an estimate of revenues and expenditures for the it succeeding year; a statement showing separately the whole ount of each appropriation of money made by law, the expenditures made thereunder and the unexpended balances: a statement showing separately the amount of money received into the state treasury, the sources from which the same has been derived, and the balances due from such sources; and finally a statement showing the amount and value of taxable property within the state. All of these items and many others of much importance are set forth in the tabular statements herein embodied.
The matter calling most urgently for attention at the present time is the condition of state finances, both present and pro- Ktively. On November 30, 1900, the floating interest-bearing of the state amounted to $1,782,485.11. On November 1902, it amounted to $1,989,328.63 — an increase of 1*06, 843. OS. This increase will be considerably augmented by the end of the biennial period for which the last legislative appropriations were made, viz , April 1, 1903. My predecessors in office for a number of years past have called attention to the gradually increasing debt of the state and the necessity for a revision of the revenue laws. Recommendations made have been passed unheeded by succe
(6)
6
legislatures. I deem it my duty to again call attention to these conditions, which have not improved during the biennium that has just expired.
The general fund appropriations made by the legislature of 1901 amounted to $2,355,977.77 for the biennium. The amount that can be realized by the general fund from the two state levies made during the biennium cannot exceed 81,657,699.31, and will probably be considerably less. The collections from miscellaneous sources during the biennium credited to the general fund will approximate $290,000. Thus the total amount that the general fund can realize from all sources will be approximately $1,947,699.31. As stated above, the appropriations amounted to $2,355,977.77, making a deficit of $408,278.46 for the biennium. That is to say. there will be approximately $408,278.46 more money spent during the two years for which the legislative appropriations of 1901 were made than can be realized from miscellaneous sources and from the two annual levies made during those years. To this amount should be added the interest paid on the floating debt. This interest is a charge against the general fund and for the biennium just expired amounted to $144,055.13. If this amount be added to the probable deficit above indicated it will make the general fund expenditures for the biennium exceed general fund receipts by $552,333.59. This has been the history of state iin;inees for several years past. Successive legislatures have appropriated not money than could possibly be realized from all sources combined durin*; the years for which the appropriations were made.
The outlook for the future under present conditions is not encouraging. It does not seem possible that the financial condition of the state can be much improved without some changes in the revenue system. It is scarcely possible to curtail appropriations to any considerable extent. Appropriations in the past have apparently not been more than sufficient to meet the expenses of the state government and the various state institutions when economically and efficiently administered; and in several instances more money could have been wisely expended.
Statement No. 4 contains an estimate of probable receipts for the fiscal period commencing April 1, 1903, and ending March 31, 1905, the \ eriod for which the appropriations of the 28th session of the legisla ure will be made. This estimate is based on actual receipts for the two years ending December 1, 1902. The actual receipts
7
for the bieunium ending March 31. 1905, cannot be much greater
than this estimate without a radical change in oar revenue system
and in the method of assessing property throughout the state.
The aggregate estimate of receipts as shown by Statement No. 4 is
$4,059,031.75 distributed as follows
General fund $2,079,068.00
School fund 1,345,181.67
University fund 560,907. 11
Normal school fund 7,865.35
State library fund 7,813.50
Penitentiary labor fund 46,841.38
Hospital for insane fund 1,354.74
Statement No. 5 contains an estimate of expenditures for the
fiscal period commencing April 1, 1903, and ending March 31, 1905.
This general estimate is based on estimates furnished by the vari-
ous departments and by the heads of institutions and aggregates
$4,737,039.67, chargeable as follows:
General fund $2,624,651.27
University fund 704,500.00
Library fund 8,000.00
Normal school fund 7,865.35
Penitentiary labor fund 46,841. S8
Temporary school fund 1,345,181.67
|«Ol
A comparison of these estimates of receipts and expenditures
for the next biennium discloses the fact that there will be a general
fund deficit approximating $555,183.27. This conclusion is baaed
upon present conditions. The only way to avoid this impending
deficit and consequent increase of the floating debt is to scale down
appropriations much below the estimate or to revise the revenue
system so that general fund receipts can be made to meet expendi-
tures.
In this connection a word should be said about University esti-
mates. The University asks for $100,000 from the general fund, and
this request is based by the regents upon what they consider the
legitimate needs and expanding usefulness of the University. The
balance of the appropriation asked by the University will be within
the amount that the various funds will realize as they exist at
present without imposing any additional burden upon the people.
While the University estimate in the aggregate seems large, it
8
from the taxpayers of the state. The balance comes from federal appropriations, from the land grant, from the endowment fund and from miscellaneous sources to which the taxpayers of the state do
not contribute.
The foregoing paragraphs indicate quite clearly that the inter-
est-bearing debt of the state has been growing from year to year and promises to so continue under present conditions. As indicated above, the only remedy is a scaling down of appropriations or a revision of the revenue system. It does not seem possible to scale down appropriations to any considerable extent, with justice to the growing needs of the state and an efficient public service. Consequently a remedy must be sought in a revision of the revenue
Bystem.
The primary cause of the decline of the revenues of the state,
I rather the failure of the revenues to respond to expenditures, been and is the low assessment of all species of property oughout the state and the escape of much property from any ation whatever. The grand assessment of the state reached its nest point in 1893, when it stood at $194,733,142. The foling table shows the assessment for each year from 1893 to 1002,
inclusive :
This table shows that from 1893 to 1897 the assessment de-
clined nearly thirty million dollars. Since 1897 there has been a
slow increase from year to year, but the assessment for 1902 is still $14,756,557 less than the assessment for 1893, and this is true notwithstanding the fact that since 1893 there has been a vast increase not only in the amount of taxable property but in values as well.
The low aggregate assessment of the state is due to the fact
that property of all kinds is assessed much below its fair cash value
893 $194,733,124.00 894 193,717,496.00
895 171,468,207.00
896 167,078,270.00
897 166,193,736.00 898 167,810,765.00
899 169,105,905.00 900 171,747,595.00
901 174,439,095.00
902 179,976,567.00
00
9
by the local assessors. The state board whose duty it is to make the levy for state purposes has no power to change this assessment. They must accept the assessment as it comes from the hands of the assessors. The action of the assessors in assessing property far below a fair cash value is perhaps in a measure due to the law itself. which in some respects does not seem to be entirely consistent. Sections 4 and 5 of the Revenue Act provide that all property shall be assessed at its fair cash value. Section 49 provides that aaw sors in the various counties shall meet on the third Tuesday of March each year "for the purpose of consultation in regard to the value of the various kinds and classes of property to be by them assessed." It was beyond doubt the intention of the framera of this section that the values agreed upon should be fair cash values. Kthe wording of the section is doubtful, and as a matter of praethe section has been loosely interpreted. Assessors have looked upon this section as giving them absolute discretion in regard to Kues, and have ignored sections 4 and 5 which provide for an asament at a fair cash value. As a result assessments have been remely low and there has been an entire absence of uniformity throughout the state. At the last meeting of assessors held in r:h, 1902, the basis of assessment agreed upon ranged all the from one-third to one-tenth. As a rule, the high assessments were in the western and less prosperous counties of the state, and the low assessments in the eastern and wealthier counties. The misinterpretation of section 49 and the action of the assessors in agreeing upon a basis of valuation much below a fair cash value has apparently created a spirit of emulation among the counties in the effort to return a low assessment. It does not seem reasonable to expect any material change in these conditions or any considerable or immediate increase in. the total assessment of the state until the law is go amended as to deprive assessors of the discretion which they have assumed under section 49. It seems to be the general consensus of opinion that an assessment of all kinds of property at a fair cash value is desirable from every point of view. In any general revision of the revenue system this should be made a fundamental consideration. The practical difficulties in the way are great as the experience of all states has demonstrated : and it seems probable that the whole question can be more thoroughly canvassed and wise measures more surely suggested by a competent commission appointed for the purpose and granted ample time within which
10
»
to do their work than by any individual or committee during the brief and busy session of the legislature.
tAn improvement in state finances, however, need not wait upon gislation of this kind. An enlargement of the powers of the board hose duty it is to make the levy for state purposes will solve the ffieulty as far as state revenues are concerned. For many years ist the board has been permitted to levy only five mills for general fund purposes and for many years under this limitation it has been impossible to make revenues meet expenditures. Unless some proision can be made for an immediate and very considerable increase n the total assessment of the state, a result that does not at this* moment seem probable, the limit for the general fund levy should te enlarged to six and one-half or seven mills. A levy of seven mills, even on the basis of present low assessments, would bring to le treasury funds sufficient to meet present current expenditures nd prevent further aocumulatou of debt. This seems to be a reasonable proposition. It does not seem to be good business manageuent for the legislature, every two years, to appropriate more loney than can be realized under the present five-mill limitation mposed by law. That has been the history of appropriations in uc state for many years past, and that has been the cause of the accumulation of a floating debt of nearly two million dollars. The iinit should be enlarged and the state board empowered to raise 11 the money the legislature appropriates. Along this easy and sensible route a very great improvement in state finances is possible.
The question may be asked what shall be done with the present floating debt. To this it may be replied that if the law can be so amended as to cause current revenues to meet current expenditures the receipts from delinquent taxes of past years will take care of a portion of the present debt. In addition to this it would perhaps be well for the legislature to authorize a small sinking fund levy for a number of years. Under such an order of business the floating debt could be rapidly cared for.
The conclusion to be drawn from the foregoing paragraphs reating to state finances, is that we can expect more satisfactory conditions either through a much higher assessment or through a larger evy, the latter method seeming to be the easiest and most practicable for immediate results. Only through the one or the other of these alternatives can sufficient revenue be secured and a further accumulation of debt be prevented.
11
The law provides that by direction and under the supervision of the auditor of public accounts, there shall be an examination of the books, accounts and affairs of each county treasurer's office in this state, not less frequently than once every two years. When I came into office I found that some of the counties had not been examined for three years, and many more had not been examined during the two years preceding. By great effort the work has been brought up to date. Every county has been examined during the biennium and these examinations have been thorough and complete. An effort has been made by the examiners to secure uniformity and system in the accounts of the various treasurers, and I believe they have accomplished much good along this line. I deem this a very valuable branch of the public service. Frequent examinations not only promote uniformity and thorough business methods in the treasurers' offices, but they are useful in correcting in their incipiency loose methods and vicious practices that ultimately lead t<> defalcations and to loss of revenue both to the state and to the counties. With the present force available, examinations cannot be made oftener than once every two years. In niy opinion it would be money well spent to extend this service, to increase the number of examiners and to pay more liberal salaries so that thoroughly competent men can be secured for the work.
Statements 8, 8 A, and 8B show the amount of taxes due the state from 1859 down to November 30, 1902. The total i- • r >'_'4.'.*7. There is included in this amount, however, the levy for 1902. not yet delinquent. The actual amount of delinquent tax is » 242. 400.36, and of this amount a very large per cent is for years or to 1890, as will be seen from an inspection of Statement B B. Thus there is $31,568.36 due for the year 18M and there is still due $15,980.83 for the year 1859. Delinquent taxes prior to 190n amount to $1,087,738.92, and it is extremely probable that only a very small per cent of this amount will ever be collected. All these balances running back to 1859 are still charged against the counties and appear on the auditoVs books as assets. They are brought forward from year to year, encumber the books and entail a great amount of useless labor. There is no way provided by law at the present time for settling with the counties with reference to these non-collectible taxes. They should not be permitted to remain in perpetuity a charge against the counties and an asset upon the books of the state. Some way should be provided by law for adjusting
12
E non-collectible balances and discharging them from the books. s a matter that should be taken into consideration in a general on of the revenue law.
Claims for wolf bounties now on file and unpaid amount to $32,000, approximately, and are continually accumulating. The legislature of 1901 appropriated $15,000 to pay claims that might thereafter accrue, but no provision was made for claims already on file. This appropriation was vetoed and the above mentioned S32.000 covers claims that have been accumulating for more than three years. This matter should receive the attention of the legislature. The law granting bounties still remains upon the statute book. These claims have accumulated under this law and there is no doubt an obligation on the part of the state to pay them. If no appropriations are to be made to cover such claims the law granting bounties should be repealed. Almost every mail brings more of these claims. They encumber the books and cause much labor and expense in the way of correspondence.
During the biennium much work has devolved upon the Bond Department. Bonds have been registered to the amount of 1,692.-357.00. This includes county, precinct, city and village and school district bonds. It seems advisable that a law should be passed authorizing the auditor to charge a registration fee of one-fourth of 1 per cent on the amount of all bonds presented for registration. Such a law was formerly in existence but was inadvertently repealed a few years ago. Its re-enactment was recommended by my predecessor and I again renew the recommendation. It also seems desirable that a law should be passed requiring county and city clerks to make regular quarterly reports to the auditor of all bonds remaining outstanding and uncancelled. In this way a complete bond record of the state may be kept. An attempt has been heretofore made to keep such a record, but the record is incomplete owing to imperfections in the law.
A summary of the insurance business of the state is embodied in this report. The work of the Insurance Department during the biennium has been voluminous, and I think has been judiciously handled. The work of this department is of great importance to the people of the state and every facility should be provided for making the work thorough and efficient. The volume of work would justify the creation of an independent department similar to those existing in many other states. Much difficulty has been ex-
13
owing to the uncertainty and imperfection of the insurance laws. These laws in many ways are out of harmony with each other. It is not possible here to point out these imperfections in detail. Experience has demonstrated that a general revision of the insurance laws of the state is greatly needed.
Insurance fees paid into the state treasury during the biennium ounted to $83,157.10. In January, 1901, the Providence- Wasliton and other insurance companies filed a request to be given dit on the current business of that year for certain amounts ich they claimed from moneys paid into the state treasury by gene Moore. Under a decision of the supreme court, reported 59 Neb., 524, some sixty insurance companies, including the >vidence- Washington, made a second payment to the state of s paid to Eugene Moore. Moore in the meantime paid 89,000 o the state treasury, and the above-mentioned insurance compas claimed that they should receive credit for their pro rata share this amount to offset the fees they had paid twice. While the Iuities of the case were with the companies, their claims for credit ¦re rejected on the ground that the money had been paid into the saeury and could not be paid out by credit or otherwise without a ecific appropriation. The Providence- Washington Company went the court to test the validity of this position. The supreme court sustained the refusal of the auditor to give credit without an appropriation: but in rendering the decision the court said: il It is clear that there is some money in the hands of the treasurer belonging to the plaintiff in error which the state is morally and legally bound to refund.'' In view of this decision and the equities in the case I recommend that the sum of $1,483.57 be appropriated by the legislature, to be refunded pro rata to the claimant companies pursuant to the opinion of the supreme court above cited.
During the year 1900 the National Life Insurance Company of Imtpelier, Vermont, by mistake, made a double payment of taxes the state. Each payment amounted to $604.79. I recommend it this amount be refunded by appropriation.
Respectfully submitted.
Charles Westo.v,
Auditor of Public Account*.
